bibl.title: Biennial Report OF THE SECRETARY OF STATE OF THE State of Nebraska FOR TWENTY-FOUR MONTHS ENDING JUNE 30, 1934

p.seg: Biennial Report OF THE SECRETARY OF STATE OF THE State of Nebraska FOR TWENTY-FOUR MONTHS ENDING JUNE 30, 1934. Harry R. Swanson, Secretary of State TO THE GOVERNOR

Office of Secretary of State Lincoln, Nebraska June 30, 1934 1 i ' - ■ ■ .-.'■■;■ ■ . ■ . ' '■'..' To The Honorable, The Governor, Charles W. Bryan, State Capitol Building, Lincoln, Nebraska. I My dear Governor: Conforming to the Statutes of the State of Nebraska, I have the honor to present herewith my report as Secretary of State, for the State of Nebraska, for the twenty-four months ending June 30, 1934. This report contains an exhibit of the affairs of the office and the method of conducting same during the biennium now closing. It also sets forth the amount of moneys expended by this Depart - ment, together with a classified statement of all moneys received by the office as fees. It further sets forth a statement of the number of corporations in - corporating, qualifying, withdrawing or dissolving; the registration of trade marks and trade names; the registration and renewal of stock brands; the granting of charters to chattel loan organizations under the provisions of Sections 45-112 to 45-123, inclusive, of the Compiled Statutes of Nebraska for 1929; and a report of the Board of Pardons. Respectfully submitted, HARRY R. SWANSON, Secretary of State

REPORT OF THE SECRETARY OF STATE CORPORATION DEPARTMENT The following table sets forth the number of articles of incorpora - tion, amendments to articles of incorporation, appointment of agents, dissolutions, etc., handled during the past twenty-four months: Total number of domestic corporations registered 4,712 Number of domestic corporations incorporated during biennium.... 842 Number of domestic corporations filing amendments 421 Number 'Of domestic corporations voluntarily dissolving 2G7 Number of domestic corporations dissolved for non-payment of taxes 496 Foreign Corporations Total number of foreign corporations registered 831 Number of foreign corporations qualified during biennium ICS Number of amendments to appointments filed 146 Number of foreign corporations volunlarily withdrawing— 122 Number of foreign corporations dissolved for non-payment of taxes 57 t Non-Profit Corporations Total number of non-profit corporations registered 945 Number of non-profit corporations incorporated during biennium 166 Number of non-profit corporations filing amendments 27 Number of non-profit corporations voluntarily dissolving 4 Number of non-profit corporations dissolved for non-payment of taxes 103 Grand Total of all corporations, domestic, foreign, and non-profit engaged m business at this date m Nebraska G. 488 TRADE MARKS Total Number of Trade Marks _ 1,850 Number of Trade Marks filed during biennium 346 STOCK BRANDS This department is charged with the assignment and registration of brands used for the purpose of marking live stock, as by the Statutes so provided. The year 1932 was the year m which all stock brands were required to be renewed. This renewal comes but once m five years, and the year 1932 being the first five year period since 1927, all stock brand owners were renewing accordingly. A summary of the business for the past twenty-four months is as follows: Total number of brands on record 13,041 Number of brands issued during the past two years 4,780

REPORT OF THE SECRETARY OP STATE BOARD OF PARDONS The Board of Pardons is composed of the Governor, Secretary ot State and Attorney General. Meetings are held at the penitentiary the second Wednesday of each month, except the month of August. The Board has jurisdiction to grant relief in all cases where the conviction is for violation of any criminal law of the state. The following tabulation shows the work of the Board during the period June 30, 1932 to July 1, 1934. In addition to the items tabulated, the Board granted ten com - mutations in jail cases; three women were paroled from the Girl's Train - ing School at Geneva; and the eight women at the penitentiary were transferred to the Reformatory for Women. REPORT OP AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS STATE OP NEBRASKA Office of the Auditor of Public Accounts Lincoln, Nebraska, December 1, 1934. Hon. Charles W. Bryan, Governor, and Members of the Fiftieth Session of the Nebraska Legislature, Lincoln, Nebraska. Dear Governor and Members: I have the honor and privilege to submit herewith my biennial report covering the two years from July 1, 1932 to June 30. 1934, as provided by law, Chapter 84-303, Compiled Statutes of Nebraska, 1929. Statement No. 1 reflects the state's resources as of June 30, 1934 and shows resources in the amount of $71,35-1. 119.57. This statement also reflects no liabilities. The statement of Resources reflects a decrease over over June 30 1932 in the amount of $9,852,764.23. This is made up principally in the amount shown for Common School Lands: Appraised value 6-30. 1934 ; 7,434 177 02 Appraised value 6-30, 1932 2l!429i795!21 Decrea8e $13,995,618.19 I am unable to account for the decrease, however, the June 30 1934 figure is correct. However, Statement No. 1A reflects the outstanding and unpaid warrants. as of June 30th and has been deducted from the treasurer's cash balance as of the same date. No computation was made of the current unpaid bills. The state of Nebraska has no bonded indebtedness. Your attention is directed to the condition of the state's treasury as shown in Schedule 1A. The cash on hand in the state treasury on June 30, 1934 totalled $6,081,230.60, as compared with the cash balance on June 30, 1932 of $5,075,155.23. These figures indicate an Increase in the cash balance over the prior two years of $1,006,075.37. This increase can be accounted lor by the excellent collection of property taxes by the county treasurers which, of course, is due to re-flnancing of various property mortgage loans by the federal government.

REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS During the fiscal years covered by this report the following warrants •were written without any additional help but with a decreased appro - priation in the last fiscal year. Fiscal Year Ended Warrants Written Amount June 30, 1933 143.691 $22,938,703.75 June 30, 1934 173,929 24,726,113.10 Nov. 30, 1934 76,464 11,241,093.59 This office examined and registered during this biennlum bonds of various subdivisions of the state In the amount of $7,137,225.27 as shown by Statement No. 8. The bonded indebtedness of various subdivisions arranged by coun - ties is shown in Statement No. 9, and the amount of bonds outstanding on June 30, 1934 totalled $93,095,800. The bonds outstanding at June 30, 1932 totalled $107,204,195, reflecting a decrease of the various sub - divisions' indebtedness of $14,108,395. Respectfully submitted, WM. B. PRICE, State Auditor.

REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS 1034 TAX LEVY RESOLUTION WHEREAS, frc m the Auditor's report it appears that there was appropriated to be ;>aid out of general fund, the sum of $11,012,667.41, for the biennium o' 1933-1934, one-half of which, plus the emergency and claims appropriated of $304,146.98, were met from the revenue of 1933, with the remainder to be met from the revenues of 1934 in the sum of $5,506,332.00 And whereas, tl ere will be available from miscellan - eous collections from the general fund not otherwise appropriated, receipts estimated at $1,059,273.45 Plus general fund collections from the Intangible Tax, estimated at 106,986.54 Plus beer tax on hand 142,399.52 Total $1,308,659.51 Balance $4,197,672.49 Which amount is increased 3 per cent in accordance with House Roll 16S, Session Laws of 1927 125,930.17 Leaving to be raised from the general fund levy $4,323,602.66 The assessed valuation of the Tangible Property of the state for 1934, as of record in the of flee of the Tax Com - missioner is $2, 05!), 678, 928, applied to which sum a levy of 2.1 mills will riise 4,325,325.75 Therefore, Be It Resolved that the general fund levy for 1934 be 2.1 mills, which will produce the estimated sum of $4,325,325.75
